results.title: Tjurunga: the story of stone age man. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description:
A central Australian journey was undertaken by the well-known naturalist, C. P. Mountford. On that journey he was accompanied by a group of Aborigines, who took him to their tribal lands and showed him the legendary rocks and caves and trees and streams, all of which are an integral part of the culture of the desert tribes. Mountford’s camera recorded on this journey some of the most beautiful country in the Australian continent - the lands of the original Australians. Companion to “Walkabout: a journey with the Aboriginals”. Originally filmed in 1946, revised in 1972.

This film, made in the Haast’s Bluff region, conatins ceremonial performances that are restricted and the film should not be screened without the express permission of the custodians.

results.title: Aboriginal canoe trees of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, South Australian Museum and Robert Edwards
results.brief_description: Aborigines of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, South Australian Museum and Robert Edwards

results.title: The Drover's wife
results.brief_description: From Henry Lawson via Russell Drysdale - the Australian myth of The Drover’s Wife retold from a different perspective. Story retold by Murray Bail. Based on Henry Lawson’s original story and inspired by Drysdale’s painting of the same name this film explores women’s invisibility in our cultural history. It uses a wide variety of commentators and visual and literary sources, and is positive and free of professional jargon. Cast features Martin Vaughan. Won Silver Award and Special Award for Acting in the General Category at the AFI Awards.

results.title: Cherith
results.creator_credit: Shirley Barrett, Francine Penrose and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Not being able to speak in tongues can be embarrassing at the very best of times. But if you are the only member of the congregation who cannot, and you are the daughter of a dynamic Revivalist preacher like Pastor Howard Spong - it’s even more distressing. And that’s just one of Cherith’s problems. This is a serious (and satirical) comedy about fundamentalist religion. This distinguished piece of film making, with a great script, direction and performance, won Best Short Fiction Film, AFI Awards in 1988.

results.title: Getting wet
results.creator_credit: P.J. Hogan, Chris Fitchett and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Fifteen-year-old Alex has always adored Brenda, who has helped his mother around the house for years, but she hardly notices him. When his mother asks Brenda to go on their annual beach holiday to help her out, Alex thinks his chance has come to impress her. But, as usual, it is his older brother Michael who gets the girl. Alex thinks he will never be happy again - until he meets Margaret and his adolescent fantasies come true.

results.title: Joy
results.creator_credit: Cate Shortland, Rachel Clements and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Thursday night. Late night shopping. Joy wants to have fun. This film follows a teenage girl as she hits the town in search of a good time. But Joy’s search for fulfillment leaves her lost and lonely at the end of the evening as we follow her to her unhappy home. By the director of ‘Somersault’ (2004). Original format 35mm/colour.
WARNING: This film contains scenes that may offend some viewers.

results.title: A Girl's own story
results.brief_description:
Set in the Beatlemania of the 1960s, this is a stylised account of girlhood - where perversion is innocent, family is strange and adulthood lonely. From the director of ‘The Piano’ (1993) and ‘In the Cut’ (2003). Original format 16mm/black and white.
WARNING: Some scenes may cause offence to some viewers.

results.title: Peel
results.brief_description: A red-headed family’s drive in the countryside begins an intrigue of awesome belligerence and obstinacy. This short student drama from the director of ‘The Piano’ (2003) was the winner of the Palme d’Or for best short film at Cannes in 1986. Original format 16 mm/colour.

results.title: Caravan park
results.brief_description: When their car breaks down on the way to Queensland, a family is forced to take up residence at a caravan park while the father tries to earn enough money to get the car repaired. Much of the film is seen through the eyes of their young son as he comes to realise some of the complexities of his parents’ relationship. Great realist film from the director of ‘Patriot Games’ (1992), ‘The Bone Collector’ (1999) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Based on the story by John Emery. Photography by Tom Cowan, editing by Anthony Buckley and production assistant, Gillian Armstrong. Original Format 16mm/black and white.

results.title: Love at first sight
results.brief_description: An unhappy couple plan a special anniversary dinner but neither realises just how “special” the other has made it. A new husband discovers that he is just the latest in a long line of young men that his powerful older wife has seduced. A gigolo versus black widow battle of the sexes from the director of ‘Babe’ (1995). Cast features June Salter and Richard Moir. Original format 16mm/black and white.
